Additional Information

  • YES BANK
    • 2004 में स्थापित, मुंबई में मुख्यालय, स्टार्टअप और व्यवसायों को अभिनव वित्तीय समाधान प्रदान करने पर ध्यान केंद्रित किया गया है।
  • DPIIT
    • उद्योग और आंतरिक व्यापार संवर्धन विभाग, एक सरकारी निकाय जो भारत में औद्योगिक विकास और नवाचार को बढ़ावा देने पर केंद्रित है।
  • स्टार्टअप इंडिया
    • भारत सरकार द्वारा धन, कर लाभ और अन्य संसाधनों के माध्यम से स्टार्टअप के विकास को बढ़ावा देने और समर्थन करने के लिए शुरू किया गया।
130
General/ Economy/ Banking Awareness
+0.5s, -0.125s
जनवरी 2025 में उपराष्ट्रपति जगदीप धनखड़ द्वारा लॉन्च की गई पुस्तक “Parliament: Powers, Functions & Privileges; A Comparative Constitutional Perspective” के लेखक कौन हैं?
एम. हमीद अंसारी
डॉ. के.एस. चौहान
फाली एस. नरीमन
हरिवंश नारायण सिंह
सली सोराबजी
Solution

सही उत्तर डॉ. के.एस. चौहान है।

In News

  • जनवरी 2025 में, भारत के उपराष्ट्रपति, जगदीप धनखड़ ने नई दिल्ली में “Parliament: Powers, Functions & Privileges; A Comparative Constitutional Perspective” शीर्षक वाली पुस्तक लॉन्च की।
  • यह पुस्तक डॉ. के.एस. चौहान द्वारा लिखी गई है, जो एक वरिष्ठ अधिवक्ता हैं।

Key Points

  • यह पुस्तक संसद की शक्तियों, कार्यों और विशेषाधिकारों पर एक तुलनात्मक संवैधानिक परिप्रेक्ष्य प्रदान करती है।
  • इसे नई दिल्ली में उपराष्ट्रपति के आवास पर लॉन्च किया गया था।
  • डॉ. के.एस. चौहान लेखक हैं और भारत में एक वरिष्ठ अधिवक्ता हैं।
  • इस लॉन्च कार्यक्रम की अध्यक्षता उपराष्ट्रपति जगदीप धनखड़ ने की थी।

Additional Information

  • जगदीप धनखड़ के बारे में
    • वर्तमान में भारत के 14वें उपराष्ट्रपति के रूप में कार्यरत हैं
    • 11 अगस्त 2022 को पदभार ग्रहण किया
  • पुस्तक के बारे में
    • शीर्षक: “Parliament: Powers, Functions & Privileges; A Comparative Constitutional Perspective”
    • विभिन्न देशों में विधायी शक्तियों और संवैधानिक तंत्रों पर केंद्रित है
  • महत्व
    • कानूनी विद्वानों, नीति निर्माताओं और संवैधानिक विशेषज्ञों के लिए उपयोगी
    • अन्य लोकतंत्रों के साथ तुलनात्मक अंतर्दृष्टि प्रदान करता है
131
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions. In the following question, a small paragraph is given from which five words have been replaced with a blank. These words represented by a letter are given below the paragraph, in random order. Rearrange these words in an appropriate order, so that these fit the blanks and give out a grammatically and meaningfully coherent paragraph.

Ketkar stood at the end of the passageway, _________out his breath. He looked ___________ out of the window, not being able to do anything to ________ Babu from running out of the building and disappearing into the_________. He was feeling scared. Twice now, he had led a ________ clerk to get away from his grasp. His client was not going to be happy about it. Ketkar dialed his client and narrated the entire episode. The person at the other end hung up without a response.

A. petty  B. helplessly  C. streets  D. puffing  E. stop

EBDAC
BACDE
ADBEC
DBECA

Directions. In the following question, a small paragraph is given from which five words have been replaced with a blank. These words represented by a letter are given below the paragraph, in random order. Rearrange these words in an appropriate order, so that these fit the blanks and give out a grammatically and meaningfully coherent paragraph.

The celebration ended after some time, and the family _________their routine. Everyone went to bed, but Sunny could not sleep that night. He kept _________in bed, and _________dreams kept haunting him. He was uneasy and _________out of bed a little later. His steps moved towards the door that held memories of his past. He moved to his Mom's room and pushed the door slightly open to check if she was sleeping or not. He was ___________at the innocence that she radiated even in her sleep.

A. sprang  B. tossing  C. awestruck  D. scary  E. resumed

Directions. In the following question, a small paragraph is given from which five words have been replaced with a blank. These words represented by a letter are given below the paragraph, in random order. Rearrange these words in an appropriate order, so that these fit the blanks and give out a grammatically and meaningfully coherent paragraph.

Coconut oil has been the home ground of hair care for us, but it is now the superpower for hair across the west too. Coconut oil is the ultimate champion towards __________hair health. The nourishing and moisturizing properties of hair are why this oil's popularity spread across the globe. Gone are the days where people __________to using products with a scary list of chemicals as the ingredients. In a world __________toward all things natural, coconut oil has emerged as a sure shot winner in the hair care mantra. With a ___________list of antioxidants, there is no other sure-shot way to _______ that your hair gets the tender love and care that it truly deserves.

It was early morning, and the sun was about to rise soon. As the sky was changing color to orange, the pilgrims on the river bank began_________.   Soon the sky changed from orange to red, and this was the moment we all were waiting for ~ sunrise. The first rays of the sun made the blue water of the river ____________. The __________started taking their dip, and a few started washing clothes. _________ view! It was a sight to __________; especially, for city dwellers, who spent almost the entire year at home due to the pandemic.

Directions. In the following question, a small paragraph is given from which five words have been replaced with a blank. Shrimati sat on a wooden bench and gave vent to her ______. She sobbed _____________, unmindful of the people around her. But this was Bombay. Nobody would come and ask her what the matter was or try to _________her. Shrimati realized her memories were making her unhappy instead of __________ her. She wiped her tears and went to the car, which was like a ___________ oven.

136
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

What was Gandhiji discussing during lunch with Pyarelalji?
The adoption of a girl.
A recitation of the Bhagavad Gita.
The Noakhali riots.
The marriage proposal of Abha Chatterjee with Kanu Gandhi.
None of the above
137
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

At what age Mahatma Gandhi died?
78
75
68
81
85
138
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

Which gun did Nathuram Godse purchase to kill Gandhi?
Mk 48 machine gun.
AK-47.
IMI Galil 7.62 Sniper.
INSAS LMG.
Beretta M1934.

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

Why Gandhi went on a fast-unto-death?
For withholding the payment to Pakistan.
For the independence of Pakistan.
For the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan.
For the release of the payment to Pakistan.
None of the above

English Language

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

Which of the following is/are correct according to the given passage?

A. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad.

B. Abha Chatterjee was the daughter of Kanu Gandhi.

C. Nathuram Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Northern region.

Only A
Both A and B
Only B
Both B and C
None of the above
141
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

Which of the following is/are correct according to the given passage?

A. Birla House was very far from the diplomatic enclave.

B. All of the assassination plotters including Madanlal Pahwa ran away.

C. Gandhi had initially been staying in the northern part of New Delhi.

Only A
Both A and B
Only B
Both B and C
Only C
142

+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

What will fit in the blank taken from the passage: ''The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948.''
Across
From
At
Under
On

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

In this question, a sentence (in bold) from the passage has been divided into five parts (A), (B), (C), (D), and (E). Read the sentence to find out whether there is any grammatical error in it. The error if any, will be in one part of the sentence. If there is no error, the answer is 'No error'. Ignore the error of punctuation if any.

According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete (A)/ plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated (B)/ by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after (C)/ India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. (D)/ No error (E)

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. But Gandhi opposed the decision and went on a fast-unto-death on 13 January 1948 to pressure the Indian government to release the payment to Pakistan. The Indian government, yielding to Gandhi, reversed its decision. Godse and his colleagues interpreted this sequence of events to be a case of Mahatma Gandhi controlling power and hurting India. On the day Gandhi went on hunger strike, Godse and his colleagues began planning how to assassinate Gandhi. Nathuram Vinayak Godse and Narayan Apte purchased a Beretta M1934. Along with purchasing the pistol, Godse and his accomplices shadowed Gandhi's movements.

Gandhi had initially been staying at the Balmiki Temple, near Gole Market in the northern part of New Delhi, and was holding his prayer meetings there. When the temple was requisitioned for sheltering refugees of the partition he moved to Birla House, a large mansion on what was then Albuquerque Road in south-central New Delhi, not far from the diplomatic enclave. Gandhi was living in two unpretentious rooms in the left wing of Birla House and conducting prayer meetings on a raised lawn behind the mansion. The first attempt to assassinate Gandhi _______ Birla House occurred on 20 January 1948. According to Stanley Wolpert, Nathuram Godse and his colleagues followed Gandhi to a park where he was speaking. One of them threw a grenade away from the crowd. The loud explosion scared the crowd, creating a chaotic stampede of people. Gandhi was left alone on the speakers' platform. The original assassination plan was to throw a second grenade, after the crowds had run away, at the isolated Gandhi. But the alleged accomplice Digambar Badge lost his courage, did not throw the second grenade, and ran away with the crowd. All of the assassination plotters ran away, except Madanlal Pahwa who was a Punjabi refugee of the Partition of India. He was arrested. Pahwa was released in 1964.

Manu (Mridula) Gandhi, called "Manuben" in Gujarati fashion, was Mahatma Gandhi's great niece (more precisely, a first cousin twice removed). She had come to join Gandhi's entourage during his peace mission to Noakhali in East Bengal, which had been gripped by communal violence. Abha Chatterjee (Abhaben Chatterjee) was a girl adopted by the Gandhis who would later marry Gandhi's nephew, Kanu Gandhi. Both young women were walking with Gandhi when he was assassinated. According to Last Glimpses Of Bapu, a memoir by Manuben Gandhi published in 1962, Mahatma Gandhi (Bapu) started the day in Birla House by listening to a recitation of the Bhagavad Gita. He then worked on a Congress constitution he wanted to publish in the Harijan, had his bath and massage at 8 a.m., and reprimanded Manuben to take care of herself since her health was not what it should be for an 18-year-old. Gandhi, aged 78, was weighed after his bath and was 109.5 pounds (49.7 kg). He then ate lunch with Pyarelalji discussing the Noakhali riots. After lunch, states Manuben, Gandhi napped. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options: 

In early September 1947, Gandhi moved to Delhi to help stem the violent rioting there and in the neighboring province of East Punjab. The rioting had come in the wake of the partition of the British Indian empire, which had accompanied the creation of the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan, and involved large, chaotic transfers of the population between them. Nathuram Vinayak Godse, and his assassination accomplices, were residents of the Deccan region. Godse had previously led a civil disobedience movement against Osman Ali Khan, the Muslim ruler of the princely Deccan region dominion of Hyderabad State in British India. Godse joined a protest march in 1938 in Hyderabad, he was arrested for political crimes and served a prison sentence. Once he was out of prison, Godse continued his civil disobedience and worked as a journalist reporting the sufferings of Hindu refugees escaping from Pakistan, and during the various religious riots that erupted in the 1940s. According to Arvind Sharma, the concrete plans to assassinate Gandhi was initiated by Godse and his accomplices in 1948, after India and Pakistan had already started a war over Kashmir. The government of India withheld the money because Pakistan could use the money against them in war. After waking up, he had a meeting with Sardar Dada. Two Kathiawar leaders wanted to meet him, and when Manuben informed Gandhi that they wanted to meet him, Gandhi replied, "Tell them that, if I remain alive, they can talk to me after the prayer on my walk".

While extremity unfortunate and utterly deplorable, (A) the attacks on civilians in Vienna on Monday night, (B) shortly before Austria went into a nationwide curfew to complement the coronavirus, (C) were not entirely unexpected. (D)

151
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the given passage carefully to answer the following questions. Each question will have five alternatives as its answer. Choose the correct option as your answer.

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

According to the passage, which of the following is NOT identified as a primary factor contributing to Veridia's Digital Divide Paradox?

A) The rapid pace of technological evolution outstripping digital education

B) An outdated and ill-suited curriculum for digital literacy

C) The scarcity of digital infrastructure investment

D) A lack of community engagement efforts

E) The presence of algorithm bias in public services

A
B
C
D
E
152
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the given passage carefully to answer the following questions. Each question will have five alternatives as its answer. Choose the correct option as your answer.

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

Which of the following public issues is highlighted in the passage as a consequence of the digital divide in Veridia?

A) Increased competition among small businesses

B) High adoption rates of Smart Governance initiatives

C) Enhanced citizen participation

D) A sense of alienation among certain demographics

E) Streamlined bureaucratic processes

A
B
C
D
E
153

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

According to the passage, which of the following statements is correct?

A) Veridia's government faces criticism for its focus on technological progress.

B) Algorithm bias has only negatively impacted the elderly population.

C) Small businesses in Veridia are not affected by the digital divide.

Only A
Only B
Only C
A and B
A and C

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

A) The city's digital education curriculum is well-suited to the population's needs.

B) "Bridging the Byte Gap" is a study documenting digital literacy issues in Veridia.

C) Veridia's Smart Governance initiative aimed to enhance citizen participation.

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

Directions: Read the given passage carefully to answer the following questions. Each question will have five alternatives as its answer. Choose the correct option as your answer.

The city of Veridia, once hailed as a paradigm of technological utopia, now finds itself ensnared in the intricate web of the "Digital Divide Paradox." This paradox, a stark testament to the unintended consequences of rapid technological advancement, manifests as a glaring discrepancy: while Veridia boasts the highest per capita investment in cutting-edge digital infrastructure globally, a disconcertingly large segment of its population remains trapped in a state of digital exclusion. This exclusion transcends the mere lack of access to hardware or internet connectivity; it delves into the realm of digital literacy, a crucial component often overlooked in the city's relentless pursuit of technological progress. A recent landmark study, "Bridging the Byte Gap," meticulously documented this phenomenon, revealing that even among those privileged with access to digital resources, digital literacy levels are alarmingly, and often shockingly, low. The study meticulously identified three primary, interconnected factors that contribute to this burgeoning paradox. Firstly, the dizzying pace of technological evolution has far outstripped the city's capacity to provide comprehensive and adaptive digital education. The curriculum, often outdated and ill-suited to the diverse needs of the population, fails to equip individuals with the necessary skills to navigate the ever-evolving digital landscape. Secondly, the city's unwavering focus on infrastructure development has overshadowed the crucial, yet often neglected, aspect of community engagement. This oversight has resulted in a profound disconnect between the technological advancements and the lived realities of the people, leading to widespread apathy and disengagement. Finally, the insidious presence of "algorithm bias," embedded within the city's public services, designed to streamline processes and enhance efficiency, has inadvertently, and often tragically, marginalized certain demographics, particularly the elderly, those with limited formal education, and individuals from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These biases, often subtle and opaque, perpetuate existing inequalities and exacerbate social divisions. The repercussions of this digital divide are far-reaching and deeply unsettling. The city's ambitious "Smart Governance" initiative, conceived as a transformative project to enhance citizen participation, streamline bureaucratic processes, and optimize resource allocation, is faltering, plagued by alarmingly low adoption rates and widespread distrust. Small businesses, the lifeblood of Veridia's economy, find themselves struggling to compete with larger, tech-savvy corporations, unable to navigate the complex digital ecosystem that increasingly dominates the market. Moreover, the social fabric of Veridia is fraying, with a palpable sense of alienation and resentment simmering among those left behind by the relentless march of the digital revolution. The government, initially brimming with optimism about the transformative power of technology, is now facing mounting criticism from all quarters for its myopic focus on technological advancement and its failure to address the human dimension of digitalization. A newly formed committee, "Equity in the Digital Age," comprising experts from various fields, is tasked with the daunting challenge of proposing viable solutions. However, the fundamental question remains: how can Veridia bridge the byte gap without compromising its cherished technological progress and sacrificing the well-being of its citizens?

Which of the following best states the central theme of the passage?
The technological advancements in Veridia are unparalleled.
Veridia's investment in digital infrastructure is globally recognized.
The Digital Divide Paradox in Veridia highlights the shortcomings in digital literacy and societal inclusion.
Algorithm biases have only minor impacts on Veridia's population.
Veridia's Smart Governance initiative has been highly successful.

You have to tell which word will best suit the respective blank. Mark (5) as your answer if the word given in bold after the blank is your answer i.e No change required.

The nuclear umbrella, we would like to believe, has secured India against the threat of ______(A)[conventional] war. We just have to contend with the irritants of terrorism and proxy warfare, and the ________(B)[ dalliance] of these patterns of violence suggests improving capacities of containment, if not ______(C)[diversion]. A few planes, warships, and submarines, some tanks, artillery and missiles, and a smattering of other military hardware — discarded generations that the great powers hive off at ______(D) [valiant] prices to what is still substantially a backward country — will not only ensure our security but put us well on our way to emerging as a global power. All we need is a healthy growth rate, and all will fall into place. Meanwhile, our internal “enemies” can simply be crushed by ______(E) [impugn]majoritarian force.

Which of the following fits in the blank labelled (A)?
Considerate
Hackneyed
Sabbatical
Sadistic
